user_prompt: What is Targetted Allele-Specific CRISPR/Cas9 Activation (TASCA)?
assistant_prompt:
TASCA is a recently developed genome-editing technology which allows the precise modification of DNA at selected genomic loci using only a sgRNA (single guide RNA) and Cas9 nuclease. The use of only a single guide RNA significantly reduces off-target effects compared to other genome-editing technologies such as Zinc Finger Nucleases (ZFNs) and Transcription Activator-Like Effector Nucleases (TALENs).

The CRISPR/Cas9 system is a prokaryotic immune system which uses a short guiding RNA to detect and destroy foreign DNA elements. The RNA directs the Cas9 endonuclease to a specific site in the genome and the nuclease recognizes the "protospacer" sequence on the foreign DNA and cuts the DNA at that site.

In TASCA, a short "activation" guide RNA is used which contains a sequence complementary to a sequence in the targeted DNA locus. When the two guide RNAs are expressed in the cell (usually as a chimeric transcript), the guide RNA that matches the activation sequence will give it priority to bind to the target DNA and the "activation" guide RNA will be able to bind to the "normal" guide RNA that would activate the Cas9 nuclease.

This gives the possibility to activate only the target locus and not affect other genomic loci which contain the "normal" guide RNA and the Cas9 nuclease.

The activation guide RNA can be designed to promote the expression of a gene of interest (that is normally silenced) or to inactivate a gene of interest, or to activate a cell's own DNA at a specific locus.

There are no ethical concerns in terms of using the TASCA technology, as the activation guide RNA is designed using publicly available algorithms and does not contain a Cas9 nuclease recognition sequence, so it does not induce Cas9 nuclease activity.

In September 2018, TASCA was featured on the cover of the journal eLIFE.

user_prompt: What is the main benefit of the fianchetto in chess openings?

The fianchetto is a common chess opening move in the King's Indian Defense and the French Defense. It is named after the "fianchetto" or "fianchettoed" position, in which the king is placed on a file next to a pawn, that is then moved to the adjacent side of the king's former square, thus positioning the pawn directly into the position of the king's former eponymous square.

The main benefit of the fianchetto is its ability to create a kingside attack, either direct or via a file, against an unsuspecting opponent. By moving the king's file to the kingside, the fianchettoed position creates a forward-facing moveable target for any piece on the opponent's side of the board. In the King's Indian Defense, the kingside attack leads to the creation of a variation known as the Grünfeld Defense, which is well known for its high-class players such as Alekhine, Keres, Botvinnik, and Smyslov. user_prompt: Who is Romain Iannetta
assistant_prompt:
Romain Iannetta (born November 24, 1988) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey left winger who played in one game in the National Hockey League (NHL) for the Colorado Avalanche during the 2012–13 season. He currently plays for the Frisco Wind, a ECHL affiliate of the Dallas Stars, as well as the Quebec Rocket of the American Hockey League (AHL).

Playing career
After playing four seasons with the Quebec Remparts of the QMJHL, Iannetta was drafted by the Colorado Avalanche in the sixth round, 179th overall at the 2008 NHL Entry Draft. He played 40 games for the Avalanche's American Hockey League (AHL) affiliate, the Colorado Eagles, in the 2011–12 season, where he scored 10 goals and 25 points. On August 17, 2012, the Avalanche recalled Iannetta from the Eagles for his first NHL game, where he recorded an assist in a 5–2 win over the Florida Panthers. Prior to his NHL stint, Iannetta played for the Colorado Eagles during the 2012 Calder Cup playoffs.

On February 25, 2013, Iannetta was assigned to play with the Avalanche's top developmental affiliate, the Colorado Springs Sky Sox, to end the regular season. He scored a goal in his first game with the Sky Sox.

On July 5, 2014, Iannetta was traded, along with a third-round pick in the 2016 NHL Entry Draft, to the Edmonton Oilers in exchange for Steve MacIntyre.

On July 1, 2015, Iannetta signed a one year contract with Swiss club, SC Bern of the National League A (NLA).
On July 5, 2016, Iannetta left the NLA, signing a one-year contract with Austrian club, EC KAC of the 2. Liga.

On July 1, 2017, Iannetta returned to EC KAC, now known as EC Visé, for the 2017–18 season.

user_prompt: Describe the governing arrangements provided by the Articles of Confederation. What were the main weaknesses of the document?
assistant_prompt:
The Articles of Confederation was a proposed constitution for the new United States of America, which was being formed out of the former colonies. The Articles was the first constitution of the United States and was developed quickly.
The Articles of Confederation were a four part treaty which outlined the relationship between the 13 independent states and the mother country, Great Britain. The Articles were signed in 1777 and reflected the political realities of the time.

The Articles were a compact document which set out the relationship between the states and the central government. The states were the main parties to the Articles, and were expected to provide troops in an instant if another state was not meeting its financial obligations. The central government had very limited power, and could generate laws, but lacked the manpower to enforce them.

The weakest aspect of the Articles was the lack of a judiciary. The Articles of Confederation provided that all disputes between the states and the federal government would be settled by the untrained and unpaid delegates. Any parties to the dispute would have no remedy in the Articles and any award would be unenforceable.

The Articles were superseded by the Constitution of the United States when the new nation was formed. The Constitution was drafted and ratified in 1789 and established the framework for the United States of America for over two centuries.
